channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Jakob Denzinger, Suspected Nazi Prison Guard, Dies at 91
item.description: Mr. Denzinger became a successful businessman in the United States after the war, but fled while under investigation by the Justice Department.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: A portrait of Jakob Denzinger at his gravesite in Croatia in 2014.

item.title: Malawi Gets Its First Grammy Nomination, With Album by Prison Inmates
item.description: The work has been an unexpected boon for the tiny African nation and now goes up against the works of well-known artists in the world music category.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI
item.media:description: Members of the Zomba prison band performing last month at the maximum security institution in Zomba, Malawi.

item.title: In Mexican Slum, Pope Francis Laments Economic Gap
item.description: By coming to Ecatepec, one of the country’s largest, poorest and most violent cities, the pope placed himself at the center of Mexico’s identity crisis.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED and JIM YARDLEY
item.media:description: Pope Francis warned against “a society of the few, and for the few” at a Mass in the Mexico City suburb of Ecatepec on Sunday.

item.title: Silao Journal: Pilgrimage in Mexico Keeps a Cowboy Tradition Alive
item.description: More 3,000 people made this year’s three-day journey to a mountaintop statue of Jesus, hoping to find redemption, a promise of rain or just a connection to the past.
item.dc:creator: PAULINA VILLEGAS
item.media:credit: Meghan Dhaliwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: The cowboys rode toward a Mass at the hill where the statue was built in the 1940s.

item.title: New Report of U.S.-Made Cluster Bomb Use by Saudis in Yemen
item.description: The report by Human Rights Watch included photos of bombs that did not explode, indicating they failed reliability standards required for U.S. export.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: The aftermath of a Saudi-led air strike in Sana, Yemen, on Sunday.

item.title: Brazil Pushes Public to Do Its Part in Fighting Zika Spread
item.description: Soldiers distributed fliers that told residents how to reduce the breeding grounds for Aedes aegypti, the mosquito that transmits Zika and other ills.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:credit: Lalo de Almeida for The New York Times
item.media:description: In São Paulo on Saturday, Brazilian military personnel handed out fliers during a national campaign to combat mosquitoes that are spreading the Zika virus.

item.title: Provisional President Elected in Haiti
item.description: Jocelerme Privert, the country’s Senate leader, will lead a caretaker government to fill the void left by last week’s departure of President Michel Martelly.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Esperanza Aguirre, an Official in Spain’s Governing Party, Quits Amid Corruption Claims
item.description: The resignation of Ms. Aguirre highlights the seriousness of corruption accusations against the Popular Party of Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:description: The longstanding leader of the Popular Party in Madrid, Esperanza Aguirre, resigned on Sunday after mounting allegations of corruption within her party. “Corruption is killing us,” Ms. Aguirre said. “I don’t have any direct responsibility, but I understand that I have a political responsibility.”

item.title: Trial of Chad’s Ex-President Is Punctuated by His Noncooperation
item.description: Guards had to confine Hissène Habré, the former president of Chad, to the defendant’s chair nearly every day for four months.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: MARLISE SIMONS
item.media:credit: Cemil Oksuz/Anadolu Agency, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The former president of Chad, Hissène Habré, at the Palais de Justice in Dakar, Senegal, in July.

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Will Merkel Pay for Doing the Right Thing?
item.description: The German chancellor needs to set limits on the number of refugees, but she also needs help from her Western allies.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Egyptian Appeals Court Orders New Trial for Officer Convicted of Manslaughter
item.description: The conviction of a police officer, who shot Shaimaa el-Sabbagh, an activist and poet, during a protest, had been hailed by human rights groups as a rare instance of public accountability.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: NOUR YOUSSEF
item.media:description: A protest in Cairo last year after Shaimaa el-Sabbagh was killed by the police near Tahrir Square.

item.title: Syria Accord Looms Over Europe Security Meeting
item.description: The failure to secure an end to the five-year conflict in Syria and worry over Russia’s military intervention there overshadowed the annual security conference in Germany.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Members of a civil defense team in Damascus, Syria, tried to put out a fire after airstrikes by pro-government forces on Sunday.

item.title: Britain Aims to Strengthen North’s Cities
item.description: Under a “Northern Powerhouse” plan, the government has pledged to build more roads and railways, invest in technology and research hubs, and even appeal to China’s development bank for funds.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Major renovation work around the Liverpool Football Club is clearing slum areas and creating new housing.

item.title: A Picture in Words From a Syrian Officer, Then Nothing
item.description: Abu al-Majd, who fought with government forces, also struck up a relationship with Times correspondents. Then he was sent to Palmyra, and disappeared.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD and HWAIDA SAAD
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Syrian soldiers seen at the Temple of Baal, an ancient stone ruin in Palmyra, Syria, during a visit by New York Times journalists in 2014.

item.title: Afghanistan Had Record Number of Civilian Casualties Last Year, U.N. Says
item.description: The United Nations documented 3,545 civilians killed, a reminder of the cost of the conflict at a time when the prospect of peace seems as distant as ever.
item.dc:creator: DAVID JOLLY
item.media:description: A Taliban suicide bomber attacked the international airport in Kabul, Afghanistan, in August of last year. The United Nations said at least 3,545 civilians were killed in the country in 2015.

item.title: Francis Admonishes Bishops in Mexico to ‘Begin Anew’
item.description: Speaking at Mexico City’s majestic Metropolitan Cathedral, the pope spared no criticism as he painted an almost biblical picture of a church seduced by power and money.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN
item.media:description: Pope Francis on his way to the National Palace in Mexico City’s central square on Saturday, the first full day of his Mexico visit.

item.title: Cuba Returns Inert Hellfire Missile to U.S.
item.description: The weapon was a training missile that was inadvertently sent from Europe, where it was used in NATO training.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: University Student in New Delhi Arrested on Sedition Complaint
item.description: The complaint against a student union president is the latest controversy to hit one of the country’s highly politicized universities.
item.dc:creator: SWATI GUPTA and NIDA NAJAR
item.media:description: Student members of the right-wing Bharatiya Janata Party on Friday protested against students at Jawaharlal Nehru University who had spoken out against capital punishment earlier in the week.

item.title: Congo Rebels Killed 6 and Kidnapped 14, Group Says
item.description: A statement from the group blamed the Allied Democratic Forces, a rebel group with origins in neighboring Uganda.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Jordan Struggles Under a Wave of Syrian Refugees
item.description: Jordan’s leaders face appeals from an overwhelmed public and from European nations urging them to stop the Syrians from heading to the West.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: RANA F. SWEIS
item.media:description: Syrian refugees on the outskirts of Mafraq, Jordan, in July. Jordan is now home to more than 1.4 million Syrians, including over 600,000 refugees who have arrived since the beginning of the conflict in 2011, according to officials.
